item.title: Senator Michael Bennet on His Long-Shot Bid for the Presidency
item.description: Senator Michael Bennet, of Colorado, one of more than twenty Democrats vying for the Party’s Presidential nomination, joins Dorothy Wickenden to discuss the race, the Party, and the President.
item.media:keywords: Democratic Party, 2020 Election, Donald Trump, Democratic Primary, Presidential Debates

item.title: What to Do in N.Y.C. This Weekend: August 2-4, 2019
item.description: Catch dozens of performances in the Bang on the Can Summer Festival at MASS MoCA, see flexn dancers at the Shed, eat Thai noodle-wrapped meatballs at Wayla, and more.
item.media:keywords: Night Life, New York City, Movies, Theatre, Music, Food, Dance
item.dc:creator: The New Yorker

item.title: Bonus Daily Cartoon: Once Upon a Time . . . In Detroit
item.description: In Barry Blitt’s Daily Cartoon, Joe Biden emerges relatively unscathed from the Democratic debate.
item.media:keywords: Cartoons, Humor, Satire, Democratic Primaries, Joe Biden
item.dc:creator: Barry Blitt

item.title: Unsung Heroes of the Internet
item.description: Matthew C. Kramer humorously illustrates the unsung heroes of the Internet, including people who post video tutorials, free yoga classes, and useful reviews.
item.dc:creator: Matthew C. Kramer

item.title: Daily Cartoon: Thursday, August 1st
item.description: Al Solomon’s Daily Cartoon stages the board-game version of the Democratic primary.
item.dc:creator: Ali Solomon

item.title: The Battle Over Barack Obama’s Legacy at the Democratic Debates
item.description: John Cassidy writes about the July 31st Democratic-primary debates, in which Joe Biden defended the Obama Administration while other candidates, including Kamala Harris, Cory Booker, and Julián Castro, argued for more progressive approaches to immigration, health care, and criminal-justice reform.
item.media:keywords: Democratic Primary, Presidential debate, Barack Obama, Joe Biden
item.dc:creator: John Cassidy

item.title: The Last Robot-Proof Job in America?
item.description: Lizzie Widdicombe writes about the seafood-delivery startup FultonFishMarket.com and its reliance on a mix of technology and human expertise.
item.media:keywords: Food, Technology, Delivery, Fulton Fish Market
item.dc:creator: Lizzie Widdicombe

item.title: Frequently Asked Questions: My Engagement
item.description: Danielle Kraese writes humorous answers to frequently asked questions about a woman’s recent engagement and the wedding-planning process.
item.dc:creator: Danielle Kraese

item.title: Margaret Atwood Reads Alice Munro
item.description: Margaret Atwood joins Deborah Treisman to read and discuss the short story “Corrie,” by Alice Munro, from a 2010 issue of the magazine.

item.title: Sara Stridsberg’s “Valerie,” Reviewed: An Extraordinary Love Letter to the Radical Feminist Valerie Solanas
item.description: Katy Waldman reviews Sara Stridsberg’s novel “Valerie,” based on the life of the radical feminist and the author of “SCUM Manifesto,” Valerie Solanas, who is best known for shooting Andy Warhol.
item.dc:creator: Katy Waldman

item.title: An Evening with Joseph Conrad
item.description: Anne Carson writes a flash-fiction short story, “An Evening with Joseph Conrad,” about Joseph Conrad and a woman who knew him in the Congo.
item.media:keywords: Short Stories, Fiction, Literature, Anne Carson
item.dc:creator: Anne Carson

item.title: During Night 2 of the Democratic Debate, Cory Booker Tests the Power of His Best Performance
item.description: Eric Lach writes on Senator Cory Booker’s impressive performance during the Democratic primary debate in Detroit, where he held his own alongside Joe Biden and Kamal Harris.
item.media:keywords: 2020 Election, Cory Booker, Democratic Party, Democrats, Debates
item.dc:creator: Eric Lach

item.title: On Night 2 of the Democratic Debate, Joe Biden Defends the Party’s Past
item.description: Benjamin Wallace-Wells writes on how, in the Democratic primary debate, in Detroit, Joe Biden was made to answer for the policies of the Democratic Party’s past.
item.media:keywords: 2020 Election, Joe Biden, Democratic Party, Democrats, Debates
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Wallace-Wells

item.title: What to Expect on the Second Night of the Democratic Debate
item.description: Eric Lach writes about what to expect on the second night of the Democratic debate in Detroit, which will feature the front-runners Joe Biden and Kamala Harris.
item.dc:creator: Eric Lach

item.title: How the Cover Song Conquered Movie Trailers
item.description: Alex Pappademas on the evolution of cover songs in movie trailers, beginning with the trailer for David Fincher’s film “The Social Network,” from 2010, by the company Mark Woollen & Associates, and in those for the blockbuster sequels and remakes of Hollywood today.
item.media:keywords: Movies, Movie Trailers, Music, The Social Network, Songs
item.dc:creator: Alex Pappademas

item.title: The Whitney Biennial Protests and the Changing Standards of Accountability in Art
item.description: Andrea K. Scott writes about the resignation of Warren B. Kanders from the board of the Whitney Museum of American Art, after a group of artists announced that they would remove their work from the Whitney Biennial to protest Kanders’s ownership of the Safariland Group, a manufacturer of tear gas whose use has been documented against migrants at the U.S.-Mexico border.
item.media:keywords: Whitney Biennial, Artforum, Artists, Civil Protests
item.dc:creator: Andrea K. Scott

item.title: Bonus Daily Cartoon: Candidate Angst
item.description: Ward Sutton’s Daily Cartoon brings the Democrats to therapy.
item.dc:creator: Ward Sutton

item.title: A Revelatory Performance by the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra
item.description: Richard Brody recommends a classical-music performance at Lincoln Center, of works by Mozart and Brahms, by the pianist Martin Helmchen and the Mostly Mozart Festival Orchestra, conducted by Louis Langrée.
item.dc:creator: Richard Brody

item.title: The Rhetoric and Reality of Donald Trump’s Racism
item.description: Robin Wright writes about Donald Trump’s appearance in Jamestown, Virginia, which is marking four hundred years since the beginning of both slavery and democracy in America.
item.dc:creator: Robin Wright

item.title: Eternal Damnations for the Twenty-first Century
item.description: Evan Lian humorously illustrates eternal damnations for the modern era.
item.dc:creator: Evan Lian

item.title: Daily Cartoon: Wednesday, July 31st
item.description: Lila Ash’s Daily Cartoon can’t beat the exposure.
item.dc:creator: Lila Ash

item.title: The Fiery Pleasures of “Blown Away,” a Reality-TV Competition for Glassblowing
item.description: Rachel Syme writes about the Netflix series “Blown Away,” where experienced glassblowers labor to create works of stunning, breakable art.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Syme

item.title: The Decline of Yelling
item.description: Amanda Petrusich writes about how yelling is no longer seen as a sign of power or authority but as a display of toxic masculinity, hubris, and privilege.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Petrusich

item.title: At the Democratic Debate, Pete Buttigieg Addresses the Age Issue
item.description: Amy Davidson Sorkin writes about the Democratic Presidential-primary debate and how Pete Buttigieg used his youth as a rhetorical tool to talk about gun control, foreign policy, and climate change.
item.dc:creator: Amy Davidson Sorkin

item.title: Things to Do During Your Karaoke Song’s Too-Long Instrumental Interlude
item.description: Claire Friedman writes a humorous list of things to do when you mistakenly choose a song with a lengthy musical interlude during karaoke with your co-workers.
item.dc:creator: Claire Friedman

item.title: CNN’s Non-Stop Hunt for Drama at the Democratic Debate
item.description: Eric Lach on how CNN handled the first night of the Democratic debate, pitting the long-shot candidates against the front-runners Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders.
item.media:keywords: 2020 Election, Debates, CNN, Democratic Party, Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders
item.dc:creator: Eric Lach

item.title: On Night 1 of the Democratic Debate, Marianne Williamson Battles the “Dark Psychic Force”
item.description: Naomi Fry writes on Marianne Williamson’s performance at the Democratic primary debate in Detroit, which added a level of rigor to her campaign.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Fry

item.title: In Night 1 of the Democratic Debate, It Was Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders Versus the Moderates
item.description: Benjamin Wallace-Wells writes on how the progressives Elizabeth Warren and Bernie Sanders were the best communicators during the first night of the Democratic primary debates, in Detroit.
item.media:keywords: 2020 Election, Democratic Party, Progressives, Elizabeth Warren, Bernie Sanders
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Wallace-Wells

item.title: The Gilroy Shooting and What the Democratic Candidates Should Remember About Justice John Paul Stevens
item.description: Adam Gopnik writes about the recent shooting at the Gilroy Garlic Festival and about Justice John Paul Stevens’s compelling dissent in District of Columbia v. Heller, in which he argued that gun-control laws are constitutional.
item.media:keywords: Guns, Mass Shootings, Supreme Court, (Justice) John Paul Stevens
item.dc:creator: Adam Gopnik

item.title: New Documents Raise Ethical and Billing Concerns About the N.R.A.’s Outside Counsel
item.description: Mike Spies on allegations, including a written statement from a former senior employee, that the N.R.A.’s outside counsel obstructed the work of N.R.A. accountants and exacerbated the organization’s financial woes as he charged it hefty legal fees.
item.media:keywords: National Rifle Association, Wayne LaPierre, N.R.A.
item.dc:creator: Mike Spies

item.title: “Screen Directors Playhouse” Let Directors Run Free
item.description: Richard Brody writes about the series “Screen Directors Playhouse,” featuring episodes by John Ford, Ida Lupino, Allan Dwan, and others, is a reproach to the bureaucratic jumble of modern television.
item.dc:creator: Richard Brody

item.title: The Democratic Debates Are an Opportunity to Speak Frankly About Trump and Race
item.description: Benjamin Wallace-Wells writes about the the second round of Democratic Presidential-primary debates, whose atmosphere has been intensified by President Trump’s bluntly racist attacks on Democratic politicians.
item.media:keywords: 2020 Presidential Election, Democratic Party, Presidential Primary
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Wallace-Wells

item.title: A Decline in Capital Investment Reveals the False Promise of Trump’s Tax Bill
item.description: John Cassidy writes about the Commerce Department’s report on the gross domestic product, released last week, which showed a sharp slowdown in capital spending by American businesses during the second quarter of this year, contrary to the Trump Administration’s predictions.
item.dc:creator: John Cassidy

item.title: Facebook’s Audacious Pitch for a Global Cryptocurrency
item.description: Sue Halpern on Facebook’s proposal, in the face of recent data-privacy scrutiny, for a new global cryptocurrency, Libra, which will operate on the investment of large corporations like Visa, Uber, and Spotify, and is designed to be used with Facebook’s digital wallet, Calibra.
item.dc:creator: Sue Halpern

item.title: The Questions Constituents Want to Ask 2020 Democratic Presidential Candidates
item.description: Nic Koller illustrates a humorous list of questions that Americans might want to ask Democratic Presidential candidates, including “How is this happening?“
item.media:keywords: Humor, Satire, Political Satire, 2020 Election, Illustrations
item.dc:creator: Nic Koller

item.title: Daily Cartoon: Tuesday, July 30th
item.description: Teresa Burns Parkhurst’s Daily Cartoon gets a gift for its pet.
item.media:keywords: Cartoons, Humor, Satire, Vacations, Pet Shops
item.dc:creator: Teresa Burns Parkhurst

item.title: Putin Denies Mitch McConnell Is Russian Asset: “He Has Never Been an Asset to Any Country”
item.description: Andy Borowitz jokes that President Vladimir Putin criticized pundits who called the Kentucky senator Mitch McConnell a Russian asset, on the basis of McConnell’s lack of use or value.
item.category: Humor / Satire from The Borowitz Report
item.media:keywords: Vladimir Putin, Mitch McConnell, Russian Spies, Russian Interference
item.dc:creator: Andy Borowitz

item.title: New Slogans for Athleisure Brands
item.description: Sam Saulsbury makes a humorous list of possible branding slogans for companies who make athleisure clothing.
item.dc:creator: Sam Saulsbury

item.title: Elizabeth Strout Reads “Motherless Child”
item.description: Deborah Treisman hosts the author Elizabeth Strout, who reads her short story “Motherless Child,” from the August 5 & 12, 2019, issue of The New Yorker.
item.category: Podcast / The Writer’s Voice: Fiction from the Magazine

item.title: Tana French on “The Witch Elm”
item.description: The author talks to Dorothy Wickenden about her latest novel, how she got started writing, and the impact of Ireland’s economic boom and collapse.

item.title: Trump’s Message to U.S. Intelligence Officials: Be Loyal or Leave
item.description: David Rohde on President Trump’s nomination of Representative John Ratcliffe, a Republican from Texas, for director of National Intelligence, and the message that it sends to U.S. intelligence agencies.
item.media:keywords: John Ratcliffe, Donald Trump, Dan Coats, Trump Administration, F.B.I., C.I.A.
item.dc:creator: David Rohde

item.title: A Clear Look at Jackson Pollock’s Breakthrough Painting, “Mural”
item.description: Louis Menand writes on Jackson Pollock’s “Mural,” an eight-by-twenty-foot painting completed in 1943, which is currently on display at the Museum of Fine Arts, in Boston.
item.media:keywords: Jackson Pollock, Painting, Art, Abstract Expressionism
item.dc:creator: Louis Menand

item.title: America!: Edgar Allan Poe’s Summer Vacation
item.description: Ali Fitzgerald humorously imagines the writer Edgar Allan Poe’s attempt at enjoying a seaside summer excursion.
item.dc:creator: Ali Fitzgerald

item.title: Brain Scans Shed New Light on Mysterious Attacks on U.S. Diplomats and Spies in Havana
item.description: Adam Entous writes about U.S. government employees who suffered mysterious brain injuries while working at the American Embassy in Havana, Cuba.
item.media:keywords: Cuba, Havana, Diplomacy, Central Intelligence Agency (C.I.A.), Department of State
item.dc:creator: Adam Entous

item.title: Daily Cartoon: Monday, July 29th
item.description: Brendan Loper’s Daily Cartoon debates whether or not to see a movie.
item.dc:creator: Brendan Loper

item.title: Donald Trump, Elijah Cummings, and the Definition of a Rodent
item.description: Jelani Cobb writes on Donald Trump’s comments about Elijah Cummings’s House district, which includes parts of Baltimore, being infested with rats.
item.dc:creator: Jelani Cobb

item.title: Wayla Makes a Persuasive Case for Noodle-Wrapped Meatballs
item.description: Shauna Lyon on the new Thai restaurant Wayla, where a dish that can take more than thirty minutes to prepare can disappear in sixty seconds flat.
item.dc:creator: Shauna Lyon

item.title: Elizabeth Strout on Returning to Olive Kitteridge
item.description: Deborah Treisman interviews Elizabeth Strout, about “Motherless Child,” her short story from the August 5, 2019, issue of The New Yorker.
item.media:keywords: Fiction, Short Stories, Literature, Maine, Parenthood
item.dc:creator: Deborah Treisman

item.title: The Mail
item.description: Letters respond to Nathan Heller’s investigation of GoFundMe campaigns, Jill Lepore’s Personal History about the loss of her friend, and Dan Chiasson’s piece on James Tate.

item.title: What P. T. Barnum Understood About America
item.description: Elizabeth Kolbert on the “Prince of Humbugs,” who was a liar, a racist, and an entertainer who would do anything for a crowd.
item.media:keywords: P. T. Barnum, Books, Biographies, Circuses
item.dc:creator: Elizabeth Kolbert
